module.title: Variables & Data Types
module.description: Master JavaScript variables, data types, and operators

lessons.title: Variables: let, const & var
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- `let` for variables that change
- `const` for values that don't change
- `var` is the old way (avoid it)
- Always prefer `const`, use `let` when needed

---

# Variables in JavaScript

Variables are containers for storing data.

## const - Constants
```js
const name = "Alice";
const age = 25;
// name = "Bob"; // Error! Can't reassign const
```

## let - Mutable variables
```js
let score = 0;
score = 10; // OK!
score = score + 5; // OK!
```

## var - The old way
```js
var old = "avoid this";
// var is function-scoped, not block-scoped
// It can cause bugs - prefer let/const
```

## Naming Rules
- Start with letter, `_`, or `$`
- Use camelCase: `myVariable`
- Be descriptive: `userName` not `u`

lessons.title: Data Types
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- **Primitives**: string, number, boolean, null, undefined
- **Objects**: arrays, objects, functions
- Use `typeof` to check types
- JavaScript is dynamically typed

---

# JavaScript Data Types

## Primitives
```js
const str = "hello";       // string
const num = 42;             // number
const bool = true;          // boolean
const nothing = null;       // null
const notDefined = undefined; // undefined
```

## typeof operator
```js
typeof "hello"  // "string"
typeof 42       // "number"
typeof true     // "boolean"
```

lessons.title: Operators & Expressions
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- Arithmetic: `+`, `-`, `*`, `/`, `%`, `**`
- Comparison: `===`, `!==`, `>`, `<`, `>=`, `<=`
- Logical: `&&`, `||`, `!`
- Always use `===` instead of `==`

---

lessons.title: Type Coercion & Conversion
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- JavaScript auto-converts types (coercion)
- `String()`, `Number()`, `Boolean()` for explicit conversion
- Falsy values: `0`, `""`, `null`, `undefined`, `NaN`, `false`
- `===` avoids coercion bugs

---

# Type Coercion
lessons.codeExample:
// Implicit coercion
console.log("5" + 3);     // "53" (string concat)
console.log("5" - 3);     // 2 (number math)
console.log("5" == 5);    // true (loose)
console.log("5" === 5);   // false (strict)

// Explicit conversion
console.log(Number("42")); // 42
console.log(String(42));   // "42"
console.log(Boolean(0));   // false
console.log(Boolean(1));   // true

exercises.title: Declare & Use Variables
exercises.description: Practice declaring variables with let and const.
exercises.instructions:
Create a component that displays a user profile:
1. Declare a `const` called `name` with the value "Alice"
2. Declare a `const` called `age` with the value 25
3. Declare a `let` called `score` with the value 0
4. Increment `score` by 10
5. Return a div showing: name, age, and the final score using template literals or JSX expressions
hints: Use const for values that won't change (name, age)
Use let for score since you need to modify it
Use {variableName} inside JSX to display values
exercises.validationPrompt: Check if the code declares name as const with 'Alice', age as const with 25, score as let starting at 0 then incremented to 10, and displays all three values in JSX
